Award.AwardTitle: CNH: When Strengths Can Become Weaknesses: Emerging Vulnerabilities in Coupled Natural Human Systems under Globalization and Climate Change
Award.AbstractNarration:
Long-lived coupled natural human systems (CNHs) are often distinguished by how they have evolved the right fit between their biophysical and social sub-systems. Researchers have characterized this fit in terms of the close feedbacks that enable a system to function well when faced with a known set of disturbance regimes. This project addresses a key question that naturally arises when these systems are exposed to a new set of disturbance regimes or novel change as is likely to occur with increased globalization and climate change: to what extent do the interdependencies that developed to strengthen the system's capacity to fit to a certain set of disturbances limit or enhance its capacity to refit to new conditions? To address this question, the project team will focus on a particular class of CNHs - small scale irrigation systems where the built infrastructure plays a critical role in resource provision. A multi-method approach will be employed that begins with the qualitative analysis of a large number of case studies to develop a typology of irrigation systems. A subset of previously examined exemplar cases will be revisited to examine how they have coped with new vulnerabilities that have emerged. In parallel, field experiments will be conducted with resource users and infrastructure providers that apply principles of behavioral economics to social dilemmas that emerge in irrigation systems in order to test the robustness of collective action to different stressors. These will be followed by laboratory experiments with college students to examine whether the findings can be generalized to other systems. Finally, insights from the case studies and experiments will be used to develop formal dynamic models of prototypical irrigation-based CNHs. Using tools from dynamical systems and robust control complemented by numerical experiments and simulation (including agent-based approaches), the qualitative dynamics and associated robustness-vulnerability characteristics of these systems will be studied in order to distill a set of institutional design principles for use in the development of tools for anticipatory governance.

In addition to the study of coupled natural human systems (CNHs) in its own right, this project is motivated by an important practical consideration. The pace at which social and natural systems are currently changing - driven to a large degree by globalization and climate change - has challenged the capacity of several CNHs to self-organize and respond effectively to this change. Ongoing field studies have shown that small scale farms (less than 2 hectares), which constitute 90% of farms worldwide and consume an estimated 70% of developed water supplies, are the most vulnerable to such changes. Since these farms also produce 40% of agricultural output globally and support the majority of world?s poorest people, it is essential to enhance their adaptive capacity in order to maintain food security and alleviate poverty. Focusing on the in-depth study of small-scale irrigation systems, this project pushes ideas of resource governance beyond traditional approaches. Rather than seeking the "best" policies for a specific system under a given set of shocks, it seeks to understand how CNHs cope with change under a wide range of disturbance regimes. The theoretical foundation for the project is based on a key insight from engineering: feedback (of which management and governance in CNHs are examples) can be used to stabilize a system and reduce its sensitivity to a given set of disturbances. However, this stabilizing feedback can increase sensitivity to new types of disturbances. By studying responses to a suite of disturbances, this project helps advance a more nuanced understanding of evolution of CNHs in terms of recognizing how in becoming finely-tuned to certain disturbances, systems become increasingly vulnerable to others. Building on this insight through theoretical modelling as well as case studies and field experiments from a wide variety of settings in the southwestern US, India, Nepal and Thailand, this project will develop a set of tools that will contribute to the capacity of policy makers to better anticipate emerging vulnerabilities and design learning and adaptive mechanisms to cope more effectively with change.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Smallholder farmers make a significant contribution to food security in developing countries. More specifically, irrigated agriculture, which consumes an estimated 70% of developed water supplies and produces 40% of global agricultural commodities from 17% of the global cropped area is practiced predominantly on small plots (90% of farms worldwide are less than 2 hectares) in developing countries where it supports the majority of the world's poorest people.

 

Smallholder irrigated agriculture is strongly dependent on water resources and investments in infrastructure shared by farmer communities. These communities are experiencing new challenges owing to integration with the broader economy (e.g., increasing price volatility) and changing weather patterns (e.g., increasing frequency of extreme weather events such as floods and droughts, late arrival of monsoons). This project focused on understanding how these communities may adapt to such change through conducting field and lab experiments on collective decision-making, comparative analysis of natural resource governance regimes, and mathematical modeling of strategic interactions between irrigators and agencies that maintain irrigation infrastructure.

 

We performed field experiments on public goods with private and collective risks in 118 small-scale rice-producing communities in four countries. Our results indicate that increasing the integration of those communities with the broader economic system is associated with lower investments in public goods when facing collective risks. These findings indicate that local public good provision may be negatively affected by collective risks, especially in communities more integrated with the market economy.  Next, we compared institutional arrangements across more than 60 case studies based on secondary data from the literature using the Institutional Design Principles developed by the late Nobel Laureate Elinor  Ostrom.  We found that to understand success or failure of governance regimes, it was not sufficient to analyze the design principles individually or in isolation.  Principles of good governance operate in clusters and are intimately intertwined with the natural and built environment.  Rather, ‘governance’ is an emergent phenomenon generated by interactions between social, economic, and environmental (both built and natural) factors.

 

Based on insights from our experimental and case-study work, we developed a formal mathematical model to explore under what circumstances stable governance structures may emerge endogenously in systems composed of shared natural, social, and built infrastructures.  We used the model to derive general conditions for a system in which critical infrastructure (e.g., canals) is provided by a governing entity that enables resource users (e.g., farmers) to sustainably produce outputs to meet their needs while supporting the governing entity.  The model suggests that small-scale irrigation systems are very sensitive to market integration and wage labor opportunities.

 

Taken together, our results suggest three key policy relevant points: 1) small-scale irrigation systems can be quite fragile to new challenges owing to integration with the broader economy and changing weather patterns, 2) effective governance of such systems should not be approached as a traditional policy problem where general policy instruments can be applied from the outside, and 3) rather, effective governance of such systems might be better seen as problem of nurturing systems to maximize the potential for the endogenous emergence of governance regimes. This project has contributed to improving our understanding of fragilities in small-scale irrigation systems and how to address them – understanding that may be critical for the food security of more than a billion people globally.

 

In addition to developing new knowledge and policy insights, this project also contributed to human resource development and knowledge infrastructure.  This project has provided interdisciplinary training for a new generation of graduate students that incorporates quantitative analytical skills (experiments and dynamic modeling), and qualitative analytical skills (comparative case-study analysis through coding and QCA). These graduate students have been highly active, organizing events with their peers around the world regarding method development and case study analysis. Project activities have thus contributed significantly to the development of human resources capable of helping address the complex problems that face society in the coming decades.  The project also contributed to educational cyberinfrastructure by updating and incorporating project outputs in the free e-textbook Sustaining the Commons that is used in graduate and undergraduate courses around the world as well as adding and refining cases in the Social-Ecological Systems Library at Arizona State University.
